Description: Say what you want

Name: freedom of press
Description: Print what you want

Name: freedom of assembly
Description: Gather when you want

Description: Worship what you want

Description: Right to bear arms

Name: 3rd Amendment of the US Constitution
Description: Quartering of troops

Description: Search and seizure

Name: Due Process Under Law
Description: Fair treatment under law

Name: eminiment domain
Description: government can take private property

Name: double jeopardy
Description: can't be charged twice

Name: self incrimination

Description: fair and speedy trial

Description: trial by jury

Name: 8th Amendment of the US Constitution
Description: cruel and unusual punishment

Description: protects rights not in bill

Description: can't sue states

Name: 12th Amendment of the US Constitution
Description: P and VP run together

Name: 13th Amendment of the US Constitution
Description: no slavery

Description: applies 4th and 5th amendments to states

Description: vote can't be denied by race

Name: 16th Amendment of the US Constitution
Description: Congress makes income tax

Name: 17th Amendment of the US Constitution
Description: Senate elected by vote

Name: 18th Amendment of the US Constitution
Description: prohibition

Name: 19th Amendment of the US Constitution
Description: women's suffrage

Name: 20th Amendment of the US Constitution
Description: shortens lame duck president

Name: 21st Amendment of the US Constitution
Description: ends prohibition

Name: 22nd Amendment of the US Constitution
Description: limit to 2 terms

Name: 23rd Amendment of the US Constitution
Description: Washington DC gets electoral votes

Name: 24th Amendment of the US Constitution
Description: no poll tax

Description: changes line of presidential succession

Description: vote at 18

Name: Marbury v. Madison
Description: Established Judicial Review

Name: Reynolds v. United States
Description: religious activity can be limited if it is criminal

Name: Engel v. Vitale
Description: No school prayer

Name: Lemon v. Kurtzman
Description: Lemon test for religion: secular purpose? advance/inhibit religion? entangle govt with religion?

Name: Wisconsin v. Yoder
Description: Amish children cannot be forced to go to school past 8th grade

Name: Sherbet v. Vernet
Description: Cannot restrict religion practice without compelling state interest

Name: Oregon v. Smith
Description: No need for compelling state interest if also illegal for general public(peyote)

Name: Schenck v. United States
Description: Clear and Present Danger Test(must show clear and present danger to limit seditious speech). Today, we use the Imminent Lawless Action Test

Name: Gitlow v. New York
Description: 1st Amendment incorporated, states can't infringe speech and press

Name: Virginia v. Loving
Description: Equal Protection, can't make laws prohibiting interracial marriage

Name: Tinker v. Des Moines School District
Description: School can regulate symbolic speech if it interferes with school operation

Name: Miller v. California
Description: Miller test(obscenity): 1. Depicts sexual conduct in offensive way? 2. lacks serious literary, artisitc, political, scientific purpose?

Name: Buckley v. Valeo
Description: struck down FECA

Name: Texas v. Johnson
Description: flag burning is protected by freedom of speech

Name: Near v. Minnesota
Description: No prior restraint

Name: New York Times v. Sullivan
Description: Can't sue for libel without actual malice(knew story was false or showed disregard for truth)

Name: New York Times v. United States (Pentagon Papers Case)
Description: National security is too vague to justify prior restraint

Name: Hazelwood School District v. Kuhlmeier
Description: School can regulate school newspaper because school has right to limit info to students

Name: District of Columbia v. Heller
Description: Firearm cannot be regulated

Name: McDonald v. Chicago
Description: Applied 2nd Amendment to states through 14th Amendment

Name: Mapp v. Ohio
Description: Exclusionary Rule applies to states through 14th Amendment

Name: Weeks v. United States
Description: Developed Exclusionary Rule(illegal evidence can't be used for a criminal trial)

Name: Katz v. United States
Description: Warrant is needed if a reasonable person would believe they have privacy

Name: Terry v. Ohio
Description: Reasonable person thinks you are suspicious police can Stop and Frisk

Name: Barron v. Baltimore
Description: Bill of Rights cannot bbe applied to states(until 14th Amendment)

Name: Miranda v. Arizona
Description: Miranda Rights must be read during arrest

Name: Gideon v. Wainwright
Description: Federal and state criminal trials must provide right to free trial

Name: Furman v. Georgia/Gregg v. Georgia
Description: Death penalty is allowed, but consistency must be used

Name: Griswold v. Connecticut
Description: Right to privacy in people's choice of use of contraception

Name: Roe v. Wade
Description: Abortion regulation: 1st trimester states must show compelling state interest, 2nd trimester states can regulate if reasonable, 3rd trimester states can limit or prevent abortion

Name: Planned Parenthood v. Casey
Description: Abortion regulation is allowed if it does not have the purpose of imposing an undue burden

Name: Plessy v. Ferguson
Description: racial segregation in public facilities is OK, "separate but equal"

Name: Korematsu v. United States
Description: Japanese camps are constitutional in times of emergency

Name: Brown v. Board of Education
Description: separate race public schools are unconstitutional

Name: Hearts of Atlanta Motel v. United States
Description: Congress can regulate local commerce, public accommodation has no right to choose guests

Name: Regents of UC v. Bakke
Description: No racial quota

Name: Gratz v. Bollinger and Grutter v. Bollinger
Description: University consideration must use specific and individual assessment and cannot use race as a primary deciding factor

Name: Citizens United v. FEC
Description: First Amendment prevents restriction on independent political expenditures by a nonprofit corporation

Name: Baker v. Carr
Description: federal courts can decide redistricting cases

Name: Pendleton Civil Service Act of 1883
Description: Government jobs awarded based on merit

Name: Hatch Act
Description: employees in executive branch cannot engage in political activity

Name: Social Security Act of 1935
Description: Established social security

Name: Taft Hartley Act of 1947
Description: Restricts activities and power of labor unions

Name: War Powers Resolution of 1973
Description: President must notify Congress within 48 hrs. of military action, armed forces cannot remain in foreign territory for more than 60 days without declaration of war

Name: Civil Rights Act of 1964
Description: Outlaw discrimination based on race, religion, sex, or national origin

Name: Voting Rights Act of 1965
Description: Prohibits racial discrimination in voting

Name: Title IX of the Educational Amendment of 1972
Description: No federally funded educational program can discriminate based on gender

Name: Clean Air Act of 1972
Description: Enforces clean air and regulates agencies pollution

Name: Clean Water Act of 1972
Description: Regulate agency's water pollution

Name: Endangered Species Act of 1973
Description: protects endangered species

Name: Congressional Budget Impoundment and Control Act of 1974
Description: Governs role of Congress in Budget process

Description: Place limits on campaign contributions

Name: Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990
Description: prohibits discrimination against disabled people

Name: Motor Voter Act of 1993
Description: require states to give voter registration opportunities

Name: Communications Decency Act of 1996
Description: regulate pornographic material on the internet

Name: Welfare Reform Act of 1996
Description: created TANF help needy families

Name: Bi-Partisan Campaign Finance Reform Act of 2002
Description: Stopped soft money and prevented ads that name a candidate within 30 days of a primary

Name: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act of 2010
Description: Obamacare, increased affordability and quality of health insurance
